conclusion: The cylinder is divided into two chambers by an insulating diaphragm of mass m.
Initially, both chambers have identical pressure p, volume V, and temperature T.
The piston is pushed upwards slowly, compressing the gas in the lower chamber and expanding the gas in the upper chamber.
The diaphragm rests on a circular ledge, and gas starts to leak when the pressure difference across the diaphragm equals the weight of the diaphragm.
The gas starts to leak when the pressure difference between the lower chamber and the upper chamber equals the force due to the weight of the diaphragm: Δp = mg/A.
The process is adiabatic because the cylinder is insulated.
For an adiabatic process, the pressure p and volume V of an ideal gas satisfy: pV^γ = constant, where γ = 5/3 for helium (a monoatomic gas).
Let the volume of the lower chamber be V_0 and the pressure in the lower chamber be p + Δp. The upper chamber will have volume 2V - V_0 and pressure p - Δp.
Using the adiabatic relation: pV^γ = (p + Δp)V_0^γ, pV^γ = (p - Δp)(2V - V_0)^γ.
Using Δp = mg/A, we can write: Δp = xp.
Substitute Δp = xp into the adiabatic relation for the lower chamber: pV^γ = (p + xp)V_0^γ.
Similarly, for the upper chamber: pV^γ = (p - xp)(2V - V_0)^γ.
Factor out p: V^γ = (1 - x)(2V - V_0)^γ.
We now have two equations: 1. V^γ = (1 + x)V_0^γ, 2. V^γ = (1 - x)(2V - V_0)^γ.
From the first equation: V_0 = V/(1 + x)^(1/γ).
Substitute V_0 into the second equation: V^γ = (1 - x)[2V - V/(1 + x)^(1/γ)]^γ.
